questions.title: Equivalences of properties of sequences
questions.content:
Consider the following properties of a sequence of real numbers $(a_n)_{n\ge0}$…:

1. $a_n\to a$, or

2. "$a_n$ eventually equals $a$" -- i.e.
$\exists N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$\forall n\ge N,\ a_n = a$, or

3. "$(a_n)$ is bounded" -- i.e. $\exists\,R\in\mathbb R$ such that
$|a_n|<R\ \ \forall n\in \mathbb N_{>0}$.

For each statement (a-e) below, which of (i-iii) is it equivalent
to? Proof?
parts:
1. $\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$\forall n\ge N,\ \forall\epsilon>0,\ |a_n-a|<\epsilon$.

2. $\forall\epsilon>0$ there are only finitely many
$n\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ for which $|a_n-a|\ge\epsilon$.

4. $\exists\,\epsilon>0$ such that
$\forall N\in\mathbb N_{>0},\ |a_n-a|<\epsilon\ \forall n\ge N$.

5. $\forall R >0\ \exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ a_n\in(a-\frac1R,a+\frac1R)$.
parts_solutions:
(a) $\iff$ (ii) because "$\forall\epsilon>0,\ |a_n-a|<\epsilon$"
is the same statement as "$a_n = a$."

(Proof: if $a_n\ne a$ then set $\epsilon:= |a_n-a| > 0$ so that
$|a_n-a| <\epsilon$ is not true.)

(b) $\iff$ (i). Suppose (b) is true. Fix any $\epsilon > 0$ and
let $n_1,\ldots, n_r$ be the finite number of $n_i$ with
$|a_{n_i}- a|\ge\epsilon$.

Set $N :=\max\{n_1,\ldots, n_r\} + 1$. Then $\forall n\ge N$ we have
$|a_n -a| < \epsilon$, so $a_n\to a$.

Suppose (i) is true. Fix any $\epsilon > 0$, then
$\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$|a_n -a| < \epsilon\ \forall n\ge N$. In particular if
$|a_n- a|\ge\epsilon$ then $n<N$ so there are only finitely many
such $n\in\mathbb N_{>0}$.}

(c) $\iff$ (iii). Suppose (c) is true and take $N = 1$. Then
$\exists\,\epsilon > 0$ such that
$|a_n -a| < \epsilon\ \forall n\ge 1$. So, by the triangle
inequality, $|a_n| < |a| + \epsilon$. Putting $R := |a| + \epsilon$
gives (iii).

Suppose (iii) is true, i.e. $\exists\, R\in\mathbb R$ such that
$|a_n|<R\ \ \forall n\in N$. By the triangle inequality, $|a_n- a| <
R + |a|\ \,\forall n\ge N$. Putting $\epsilon := R + |a|$ proves
(c).

(d) \iff (iii). Suppose (d) is true and take $N = 1$. Then
$|a_n -a| < \epsilon\ \forall n\ge 1$. So, by the triangle
inequality, $|a_n| < |a| +\epsilon$. Putting $R := |a| + \epsilon$
gives (iii).

Suppose (iii) is true, i.e. $\exists\, R\in\mathbb R$ such that
$|a_n|<R\ \ \forall n\in N$. By the triangle inequality,
$|a_n - a| <
R + |a|\ \forall n\ge N$. Putting $\epsilon:= R + |a|$ proves (d).

(e) \iff (i): just replace \epsilon by \frac1R in the definition
of convergence.

questions.title: Convergence in the Complex Plane
questions.content:
Given a sequence $(a_n)_{n\ge1}$ of *complex* numbers, define what
a_n\to a means. For $x,y\in\mathbb R$ and $z:=x+iy\in\mathbb C$
show $\max(|x|,|y|)\ \le\ |z|\ \le\ \sqrt2\max(|x|,|y|),$ and
$$a_n\to a+ib\in\mathbb C\quad\iff\quad \mathrm{Re}(a_n)\to a \quad\mathrm{and\quad Im}(a_n)\to b.$$
parts:
Given a sequence $(a_n)_{n\ge1}$ of *complex* numbers, define what
a_n\to a means. For $x,y\in\mathbb R$ and $z:=x+iy\in\mathbb C$
show $\max(|x|,|y|)\ \le\ |z|\ \le\ \sqrt2\max(|x|,|y|),$ and
$$a_n\to a+ib\in\mathbb C\quad\iff\quad \mathrm{Re}(a_n)\to a \quad\mathrm{and\quad Im}(a_n)\to b.$$
parts_solutions:
The inequalties
$$\max(x^2,y^2)\ \le\ x^2+y^2\ \le\ \max(x^2,y^2)+\max(x^2,y^2)$$
give $$\max(|x|,|y|)^2\ \le\ |z|^2\ \le\ 2\max(|x|,|y|)^2.$$ Suppose
a_n\to a+ib and fix any $\epsilon>0$. Then
$\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$$n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n-(a+ib)|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ \max(|\mathrm{Re}(a_n)-a|,|\mathrm{Im}(a_n)-b|)<\epsilon,$$
using the first stated inequality. Therefore
$|\mathrm{Re}(a_n)-a|<\epsilon$ and $|\mathrm{Im}(a_n)-b|<\epsilon$
as required.

Conversely, suppose
$\mathrm{Re}(a_n)\to a \quad\mathrm{and\quad Im}(a_n)\to b$ and fix
any $\epsilon>0$. Then $\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |\mathrm{Re}(a_n)-a|<\epsilon/\sqrt 2$ and
$|\mathrm{Im}(a_n)-b|<\epsilon/\sqrt 2$. Thus
$$|a_n-(a+ib)|\ <\ \sqrt 2\max(|\mathrm{Re}(a_n)-a|,|\mathrm{Im}(a_n)-b|)\ <\ \sqrt 2\epsilon/\sqrt 2\ =\ \epsilon,$$
using the second stated inequality.

questions.title: Squeeze Theorem for Sequences
questions.content:
Suppose that $a_n\le b_n\le c_n\ \forall n$ and that $a_n\to a$ and
$c_n\to a$. Prove that $b_n\to a$.
parts:
Suppose that $a_n\le b_n\le c_n\ \forall n$ and that $a_n\to a$ and
$c_n\to a$. Prove that $b_n\to a$.
parts_solutions:
$\exists\, N_1\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
n\ge N_1\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n-a|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ a_n>a-\epsilon.$

$\exists\, N_2\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
n\ge N_2\ \Rightarrow\ |c_n-a|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ c_n<a+\epsilon.$

Set $N:=\max(N_1,N_2)$. Then
n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ a-\epsilon<a_n\le b_n\le c_n<a+\epsilon$.
Therefore $|b_n-a|<\epsilon$.}

$\exists\, N_1\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
n\ge N_1\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n-a|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ a_n>a-\epsilon.$

$\exists\, N_2\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
n\ge N_2\ \Rightarrow\ |c_n-a|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ c_n<a+\epsilon.$

Set $N:=\max(N_1,N_2)$. Then
n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ a-\epsilon<a_n\le b_n\le c_n<a+\epsilon$.
Therefore $|b_n-a|<\epsilon$.

questions.title: Convergence of product of sequences
questions.content:
Suppose that $a_n\to0$ and $(b_n)$ is bounded. Prove that
$a_nb_n\to0$.
parts:
Suppose that $a_n\to0$ and $(b_n)$ is bounded. Prove that
$a_nb_n\to0$.
parts_solutions:
$\exists\, B>0$ such that $|b_n|\le B\ \forall n$.

Given $\epsilon>0,\ \exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n|<\epsilon/B$.

Therefore $|a_nb_n|=|a_n||b_n|\le(\epsilon/B)B=\epsilon$, as
required.

questions.title: Boundedness of the sequence and bound on $b_n$
questions.content:
$\!\!$ Suppose that $(a_n)$ and $(b_n)$ are sequences of real
numbers such that $a_n\to a$ and $b_n\to b\ne0$. Prove that the set
$\{a_n\colon n\in\mathbb N_{>0}\}$ is bounded and that
$$\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0} \quad\mathrm{such\ that}\quad n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n|>|b|/2.$$
parts: Prove that the set $\{a_n\colon n\in\mathbb N_{>0}\}$ is bounded.
Prove that $$\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0} \quad\mathrm{such\ that}\quad n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n|>|b|/2.$$
parts_solutions: Set $\epsilon=|b|/2>0$. Then $\exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that $$n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n-b|<\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ |b|<|b_n|+\epsilon\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n|>|b|-\epsilon=|b|/2.$$

questions.title: Limit of quotient of sequences
questions.content:
Therefore $(a_n/b_n)_{n\ge N}$ is a sequence of real numbers; prove
it tends to $a/b$.
parts:
Therefore $(a_n/b_n)_{n\ge N}$ is a sequence of real numbers; prove
it tends to $a/b$.
parts_solutions:
$$\left|\frac{a_n}{b_n}-\frac ab\right|\ =\ \left|\frac{a_nb-ab_n}{bb_n}\right|\ =\ \left|\frac{(a_n-a)b+a(b-b_n)}{bb_n}\right|\ \le\ \left|\frac{(a_n-a)}{b_n}\right|+
\left|\frac{a(b-b_n)}{bb_n}\right|.$$ From above we can find
$N_1\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N_1\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n|\ge|b|/2$, which in turn implies that
$$\left|\frac{a_n}{b_n}-\frac ab\right|\ \le\ \frac{|a_n-a|}{|b|/2}+
|a|\frac{|b-b_n|}{|b|.|b|/2}\ =\ \frac{2}{|b|}|a_n-a|+
\frac{2|a|}{b^2}|b-b_n|.$$ Now fix any $\epsilon>0$. There exists
$N_2\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N_2\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n-a|<|b|\epsilon/4$. And there exists
$N_3\in\mathbb N_{>0}$ such that
$n\ge N_3\ \Rightarrow\ |b_n-b|<|b|^2\epsilon/4(1+|a|)$.\n
Therefore if we set $N:=\max\{N_1,N_2,N_3\}$ then
$$n\ge N\ \ \Rightarrow\ \ \left|\frac{a_n}{b_n}-\frac ab\right|\ <\ \frac{2|b|\epsilon/4}{|b|}+\n\frac{2|a|}{b^2}\frac{b^2\epsilon}{4(1+|a|)}\ <\ \epsilon/2+\epsilon/2\ =\ \epsilon.$$

questions.title: Sorta-Cauchy sequences and divergence
questions.content:
We call a sequence *sorta-Cauchy* if it satisfies the condition
$$\forall\epsilon>0\ \exists\, N\in\mathbb N_{>0}\ \ n\ge N\ \Rightarrow\ |a_n-a_{n+1}|<\epsilon.$$
parts:
Give an example of a sorta-Cauchy sequence which diverges to
$+\infty$. Conclude that sorta-Cauchy is not as strong as Cauchy.
parts_solutions: Any $a_n$ that increases so slowly to infinity that $a_{n+1}-a_n$ converges to zero. Eg $a_n=\sqrt n$ or $a_n=\log n$ or $a_n=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac 1i$.

questions.title: Cauchy sequence in \mathbb Q not converging in \mathbb Q
questions.content:
Give an example of a Cauchy sequence in $\mathbb Q$ which does not
converge in $\mathbb Q$.
parts:
We know that in $\mathbb R$, a sequence is Cauchy if and only if it
is convergent. Show that it is impossible to prove this using only
the arithmetic and order axioms of $\mathbb R$ (i.e. all the axioms
except the completeness axioms -- the one about the existence of
least upper bounds).
parts_solutions:
Suppose that we could prove that a sequence is Cauchy if and only if
it is convergent with only the arithmetic and order axioms. We know
in $\mathbb Q$ that the order and arithmetic axioms hold, this would
suggest that any Cauchy sequence in $\mathbb Q$ must converge in
$\mathbb Q$. This is a contradiction since we have just shown that
there are Cauchy sequences in $\mathbb Q$ that do not converge in
$\mathbb Q$ in the first part of this question.

questions.title: Bounded sequence and supremum of sets
questions.content: Let $(a_{n})_{n \in \mathbb N_{>0}}$ be a bounded sequence.
parts:
For each $n \in \mathbb N_{>0}$, define the set
$S_{n} = \{ a_{j}: j \ge n\}$. Prove that, for every
$n \in \mathbb N_{>0}$, there exists some $b_{n} \in \mathbb{R}$
such that $b_{n} = \sup(S_{n})$.
parts_solutions: Let $M$ be an upper bound for $(a_{n})_{n \in \mathbb N_{>0}}$, then the set $S_{n}$ is non-empty with $M$ as an upper bound, so by the completeness axiom $S_{n}$ has a supremum.

questions.title: Existence of the Limit Supremum of a Sequence
questions.content:
Let $B = \{ b_{n}: n \in \mathbb N_{>0}\}$ where $b_{n}$ is
defined as above. Prove that there exists some
$l \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $l = \inf(B)$.
parts:
(Remark: $l$ is
called the limit supremum of the sequence
$(a_{n})_{n \in \mathbb N_{>0}}$, and the usual notation is
$l = \limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}$).
parts_solutions:
The set $B$ is clearly non-empty. Let $\tilde{M}$ be a lower
bound for $(a_{n})_{n \in \mathbb N_{>0}}$. Then
$b_{n} = \sup(S_{n}) \ge \tilde{M}$. This means $\tilde{M}$ is a
lower bound for $B$ and so by the completeness axiom, $B$ has an
infimum.

questions.title: Limit superior of sequences
questions.content:
For each of the sequences below, find the value of
$\limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}$ and give justification
for your answer.
parts_solutions:
$\limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n} = 1$. Note that, for
every $j \in \mathbb N_{>0}$, one has $S_{j} = \{-1,1\}$ so
that $b_{j} = \sup(S_{j}) = 1$. Therefore
$\limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}  = \inf \{1\} = 1$.

questions.title: Limit Superior and Infimum of a Sequence
parts_solutions:
$\limsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n} = 0$. Note that, for
every $j \in \mathbb N_{>0}$, one has
$b_{j} = \sup(S_{j}) = \frac{1}{j}$ for $j$ even and
$\frac{1}{j+1}$ for $j$ odd. Therefore we argue that
$\inf(B) = 0$. Clearly $0$ is a lower bound. To show that it
is an infimum, we show that for any $\epsilon > 0$, there
exists $b \in B$ such that $b - \epsilon < 0$. Note that, by
the Archimedean Axiom, we can find an $j \in \mathbb N_{>0}$
such that $j \ge \frac{1}{\epsilon}$, so that
$\frac{1}{j} < \epsilon$. It then follows that
$b_{j} - \epsilon < 0$, which finishes the proof since
$b_{j} \in B$.
